merged_dataset_groups.topic_summary: The BSD400 dataset is extensively used for evaluating and training image restoration models, particularly in denoising, deblurring, dehazing, and deraining. It provides high-quality, diverse images, including urban scenes and synthetic degradations, to assess model performance across various noise levels and degradation types. The dataset supports both single-task and multi-degradation restoration, enhancing model robustness and generalization. It is also used for benchmarking, ablation studies, and evaluating segmentation accuracy.

The Rain100L dataset is primarily used for image restoration tasks, particularly deraining, deblurring, denoising, dehazing, and low-light enhancement. It contains 200 training and 100 testing image pairs for deraining, and is often combined with other datasets like BSD400 and WED for enhanced performance. Deep learning techniques are commonly employed to address specific issues such as rain streak removal, noise reduction, and visibility improvement in various conditions. The dataset supports the evaluation and comparison of different restoration methods, focusing on texture preservation, sharpness, and overall image quality.

The RESIDE dataset is extensively used for training and evaluating various image restoration models, particularly in dehazing, deraining, low-light image enhancement, and motion deblurring. It provides paired images (e.g., hazy/clear, rainy/clear, low-light/normal-light, blurred/sharp) to train deep learning models and assess their performance. The dataset includes both synthetic and real-world images, enabling researchers to test algorithms under diverse conditions, such as varying degrees of haze, rain, low light, and motion blur. Specific subsets like the Outdoor Training Set (OTS) and Synthetic Outdoor Testing Set (SOTS) are used for benchmarking and validating dehazing models, while other subsets focus on deraining, low-light enhancement, and motion deblurring. The dataset's comprehensive nature supports a wide range of image restoration tasks, ensuring robust and reliable model evaluation.

The GoPro dataset is extensively used for training and testing various image restoration models, including deblurring, low-light enhancement, deraining, dehazing, and denoising. It consists of paired images (blurred/sharp, low-light/normal, rainy/clear, hazy/clear) and is employed to evaluate and compare the performance of deep learning methods, such as multi-scale convolutional neural networks, in enhancing image quality across different challenging conditions. The dataset supports both quantitative and qualitative assessments, enabling researchers to validate their models against state-of-the-art techniques.

The BSD68 dataset is primarily used to evaluate and compare image restoration methods, with a focus on denoising, super-resolution, and deblurring techniques. It is employed in both single-task and multi-task settings, assessing performance metrics and visual quality on natural and urban scene images. The dataset's high-resolution and diverse content make it suitable for benchmarking restoration algorithms, particularly in denoising and enhancing image clarity and detail.

The LOL dataset is extensively used for evaluating various image restoration tasks, including low-light image enhancement, deraining, deblurring, dehazing, desnowing, and super-resolution. It is employed to assess the performance of deep learning models, particularly focusing on improving image quality under challenging conditions such as low light, rain, haze, and motion blur. The dataset's official splits (e.g., 485:15, 5600:50) are used for training and testing, and common metrics like PSNR and SSIM are utilized to compare the proposed methods against state-of-the-art techniques.

The Snow100K dataset is primarily used for training and evaluating image desnowing algorithms, providing a large set of synthetic and real-world snow images. It is utilized to enhance model robustness and generalization, focusing on performance metrics and visual quality improvements. The dataset supports comprehensive evaluations of single image desnowing algorithms, addressing various snow intensities and complex scenes. It also facilitates comparisons between different desnowing methods and models, such as the AIRFormer, using metrics like PSNR and visual assessments. Additionally, it is used for training and evaluating rain removal and underwater image enhancement algorithms, though its primary focus remains on snow removal.

The Rain200L dataset is extensively used to evaluate and train deraining methods, focusing on both high-resolution and low-resolution synthetic rain images to assess performance in removing heavy and light rain. It is also utilized for dehazing, denoising, deblurring, and low-light enhancement tasks, providing diverse image conditions to improve the robustness and generalization of image restoration techniques. The dataset's large set of synthetic images enables comprehensive evaluation and training, enhancing the effectiveness of models in handling various image degradations.

The DIV2K dataset is extensively used in image restoration research, particularly for training and evaluating models in super-resolution, denoising, deblurring, dehazing, rain removal, and low-light enhancement. It provides high-quality, diverse images for robust model training and benchmarking. The dataset supports various tasks, including enhancing image resolution at x8 and x4 scales, removing real-world noise patterns, and improving visual clarity in challenging conditions like rain, haze, and low light. Its high-resolution images and ground truth pairs enable comprehensive performance assessments and method validations.

The WED dataset is extensively used for training and evaluating image restoration models, particularly in denoising, dehazing, deraining, and low-light enhancement. It provides a diverse set of images with various degradations, including noise, rain, haze, and blur, enabling researchers to test the robustness and effectiveness of their methods across different conditions. The dataset is crucial for benchmarking performance, assessing visual quality, and ensuring adaptability to real-world and synthetic scenarios.

The SOTS dataset is primarily used for benchmarking and evaluating single-image dehazing methods, featuring 72,135 training and 500 testing images. It is employed to assess the performance of dehazing algorithms on both synthetic and real-world hazy images, focusing on image quality and restoration effectiveness. Additionally, the dataset is used for image denoising and deraining, enhancing urban and natural scene image quality through various restoration techniques. It supports visual comparisons with state-of-the-art models and trains dehazing algorithms, enabling comprehensive evaluation and improvement of image restoration methods.

The EUVP dataset is primarily used for training and evaluating image restoration algorithms, particularly in underwater image enhancement and weather-related image degradation (snow and rain removal). It provides pairs of degraded and clean images, enabling researchers to focus on improving visual perception through specific image processing techniques. The dataset supports the comparison and evaluation of different models and methods, with specific applications in enhancing underwater visual perception and removing environmental degradations like rain and snow.

The All-Weather dataset is used for training and evaluating models in image restoration tasks, particularly focusing on handling various adverse weather conditions such as rain, snow, and fog. It provides a large set of high-resolution images with diverse real-world weather degradations, enabling researchers to assess the robustness, generalization, and effectiveness of their methods. The dataset supports the development of models that can restore image clarity, detail, and scene coherence, demonstrating both subjective and objective improvements over existing techniques.

The SIDD dataset is extensively used for various image restoration tasks, including low-light image enhancement, deblurring, rain and raindrop removal, dehazing, and super-resolution. It provides paired images (e.g., low-light and well-exposed, hazy and clear, noisy and clean) for training and evaluating restoration models. The dataset supports research in improving image quality under diverse conditions, such as atmospheric haze, motion blur, and low-light environments, and is crucial for benchmarking denoising algorithms.

The O-HAZE dataset is primarily used to evaluate and benchmark image restoration methods, particularly focusing on dehazing, deraining, and desnowing performance. It provides real-world and synthetic images with various degradations, enabling researchers to assess the generalization and effectiveness of models on unseen data. The dataset includes real hazy, rainy, snowy, and low-light images, facilitating the comparison of state-of-the-art methods in terms of PSNR gains and visual quality improvements.

The Rain200H dataset is primarily used to evaluate and train deraining methods, focusing on synthetic rain images at various resolutions and intensities. It is also utilized to assess other image restoration tasks such as snow removal, haze removal, raindrop removal, and low-light enhancement. The dataset's large scale and diverse synthetic degradations enable researchers to test the robustness and generalization of their models across multiple degradations, including combined rain and snow, rain and haze, and low-light conditions.

The RSID dataset is used to compare various image restoration methods, particularly focusing on dehazing and restoration techniques for remote sensing images. Researchers employ this dataset to evaluate the effectiveness of different algorithms in enhancing image clarity and quality. The dataset's relevance lies in its application to remote sensing, enabling detailed analysis and comparison of restoration methodologies.

The Urban100 dataset is extensively used to evaluate image restoration techniques, particularly in urban scenes with diverse textures and structures. It is employed to assess performance in denoising, deraining, dehazing, deblurring, and super-resolution tasks, often at various noise levels and degradation types. The dataset's high-resolution images and realistic scenarios make it a standard benchmark for testing and comparing different restoration algorithms, including those that handle multiple degradations simultaneously.

The BSD100 dataset is extensively used for evaluating and training models in various image restoration tasks, including rain removal, super-resolution, deblurring, and image denoising. It provides high-quality images, synthetic and real rain images, blurred and clear image pairs, and low-light and normal-light image pairs. The dataset is particularly useful for assessing the robustness and effectiveness of algorithms in challenging conditions such as heavy rain, motion blur, and low-light environments. It also supports specific applications like enhancing manga images and urban scenes, making it a versatile resource for improving image quality and detail.

The Rain14000 dataset is primarily used for deraining, denoising, dehazing, and deblurring tasks. It provides a diverse set of images with varied rain intensities, noise levels, haze, and motion blur, suitable for training and evaluating image restoration models. The dataset includes both synthetic and real-world images, enabling robustness testing and performance assessment across different conditions. It is particularly useful for assessing the effectiveness of models in removing rain streaks, noise, haze, and blur while preserving image details.

The Test1 dataset is primarily used for evaluating image restoration models, with a focus on general image quality and restoration accuracy. It is specifically employed to assess the effectiveness of methods in removing raindrops and snow from images, using performance metrics and visual quality as key evaluation criteria. This dataset enables researchers to compare and validate the performance of different restoration techniques, such as the proposed AIRFormer in deraining tasks.

The HIDE dataset is primarily used for evaluating and training image restoration methods, with a strong focus on deblurring high-resolution images. It is employed to assess the performance of these methods, particularly in handling complex distortions and real-world blurring conditions. The dataset supports both quantitative evaluations and robustness testing, enabling researchers to compare their techniques against state-of-the-art methods and validate the effectiveness of their models on diverse and challenging image sets.

The NH-HAZE dataset is used for a variety of image restoration tasks, including deraining, dehazing, desnowing, and motion deblurring. It provides both synthetic and real-world images with non-homogeneous hazy, rainy, snowy, and blurred conditions for training and evaluating restoration models. The dataset is also utilized to assess the performance of denoising algorithms, particularly for smartphone camera images, and to validate super-resolution techniques, focusing on real-world low-resolution to high-resolution image pairs. Its diverse and realistic image conditions enable researchers to test the robustness and effectiveness of their algorithms in various challenging scenarios.

The Rain100H dataset is primarily used for training and evaluating de-raining models, focusing on synthetic rain images with varying intensities and complexities. It provides a benchmark set of 100 low- and high-resolution images to assess the performance of models in removing rain streaks while preserving image details. Additionally, the dataset is utilized for low-light enhancement, desnowing, and general image restoration, offering a diverse set of images to test and improve various restoration techniques.

The Test1200 dataset is primarily used for evaluating the performance of various image restoration techniques, including deraining, desnowing, denoising, JPEG artifact removal, and low-light enhancement. It is employed to assess the effectiveness of these algorithms across different scales and conditions, such as urban scenes, real-world rain images, and varying noise levels (σ = 15, 25, 50). The dataset provides a benchmark for comparing methods and improving image quality in challenging environments.

The AVIRIS dataset is used to evaluate the performance of hyperspectral image (HSI) restoration methods, particularly PromptHSI, by assessing their effectiveness in handling synthesized composite degradations. This involves comparing PromptHSI against other HSI restoration techniques to address specific research questions related to image quality and restoration accuracy. The dataset's hyperspectral characteristics enable detailed analysis of restoration methodologies under controlled degradation conditions.

The Polyu dataset is used for various image restoration tasks, including low-light image enhancement, rain removal, denoising, underwater image enhancement, and dehazing. It provides benchmarks for evaluating and comparing different algorithms in these areas. The dataset includes real and synthetic images along with their enhanced or clean versions, enabling researchers to train, test, and validate their methods effectively.

The Rain1200 dataset is primarily used for synthesizing images with rain and snow degradation to evaluate the effectiveness of image restoration techniques, including deraining and desnowing. It is also employed for dehazing tasks, using the outdoor subset to assess dehazing algorithms. The dataset supports a comprehensive benchmark across seven image restoration tasks, enabling researchers to test the versatility and performance of their methods.

The Raindrop dataset is primarily used for training and evaluating image restoration algorithms, particularly focusing on removing raindrops, snow, and other weather-related degradations. It includes 818 image pairs for raindrop removal, 9,001 pairs for snow removal, and 8,250 pairs for heavy rain restoration. Researchers use these images to enhance the effectiveness of restoration models, addressing realistic raindrop effects and heavy weather conditions. The dataset's diverse and realistic image sets enable comprehensive testing and improvement of image restoration techniques.

The Rain1400 dataset is extensively used for various image restoration tasks, including real denoising, raindrop removal, dehazing, deraining, desnowing, defocus deblurring, and JPEG artifact removal. It contains 12,600 pairs of rainy-clean images for training and 1,400 for testing, enabling researchers to benchmark and evaluate the performance of algorithms in diverse environmental conditions and synthetic scenarios. The dataset supports the development and testing of models for removing rain streaks, raindrops, haze, snow, and other image degradations, as well as addressing noise and blur.

The CBSD68 dataset is primarily used for training and testing various image restoration tasks, including dehazing, denoising, and deraining. It provides paired images for model development and benchmarking, enabling researchers to evaluate performance on specific challenges like real-world outdoor scenes and urban environments. The dataset's 68 color images are particularly useful for assessing the effectiveness of restoration techniques in diverse conditions.

The DPDD dataset is primarily used for evaluating single-image defocus deblurring methods. It provides dual-pixel data, which is crucial for consistent performance assessment. Researchers use the dataset to compare PSNR gains and parameter efficiency of their models against benchmarks like Restormer. The dataset enables detailed analysis of the relationship between model complexity and defocus deblurring performance, verifying the effectiveness of various networks in removing defocus blur from images.

The 'merged dataset' is utilized in All-in-One Image Restoration research, specifically for deblurring, de-hazing, deraining, low-light enhancement, and desnowing. It combines data from multiple sources to address various image degradation issues. The dataset enables researchers to develop and test algorithms that improve image clarity, color fidelity, and visibility under different challenging conditions, such as motion blur, atmospheric haze, rain, low light, and snow.

The REVIDE dataset is used for various image restoration tasks, including contrast enhancement, video deblurring, image deblurring, rain removal, low-light image enhancement, and haze removal. It provides multi-exposure images, sharp and blurred image pairs, synthetic and real rain images, low-light and normal-light image pairs, and real-world hazy images. These diverse data types enable researchers to train and evaluate models for specific restoration tasks, as well as test the generalization capabilities of these models on real-world scenarios.

The LHP dataset is used for evaluating the effectiveness of models in various real-world image restoration tasks, including desnowing, de-raining, low-light enhancement, and raindrop removal. It also tests the generalization capabilities of models on dehazing, under-display camera images, and overall image enhancement. The dataset contains a diverse range of images (284 for dehazing, 30 for under-display camera, 565 for enhancement, 1000 for hazy), enabling comprehensive assessment of model performance across different conditions.

The Google Landmarks dataset is used to train and evaluate image restoration models, particularly focusing on high-quality images with NIMA scores > 4.90 and short-edge resolution > 400 pixels. It serves as a large-scale benchmark containing five million images of diverse landmarks worldwide, enabling researchers to address the challenge of restoring and enhancing images from a wide range of real-world scenes.

The RESIDED-OTS dataset is primarily used for evaluating and enhancing image restoration techniques in various environmental contexts, including land, water, and underwater scenes. It incorporates depth information to improve image quality, detail, and visibility. Researchers use the dataset to train and test models, focusing on dehazing, low-light enhancement, and color correction. The dataset provides both synthetic and real-world images, enabling comprehensive performance evaluations using metrics like PSNR, SSIM, and NIQE.

The RWBI dataset is primarily used as an unseen dataset to evaluate and improve various image restoration algorithms, including deraining, deblurring, and low-light enhancement. It focuses on real-world scenarios, such as stereo image deraining, real-world blur, and complex lighting conditions, enabling researchers to benchmark performance and address challenging degradation scenarios. The dataset's emphasis on practical, real-world conditions enhances the robustness and applicability of image restoration techniques.

The MC-Blur dataset is primarily used to evaluate and advance deblurring algorithms, particularly in real-world scenarios involving motion, ultra-high-definition, and defocus blur. It serves as an unseen dataset to benchmark performance and is also utilized for evaluating deraining algorithms, especially in the context of stereo image deraining and semantic understanding. This dataset enables researchers to test the robustness and effectiveness of their algorithms in diverse and challenging conditions.

The 'Rain-Haze-Snow' dataset is used to train and evaluate neural architectures for all-in-one image restoration, specifically targeting rain, haze, and snow removal. It supports the development of both single-encoder, multi-decoder frameworks and neural architecture search methods, enabling researchers to address weather-based image degradations effectively.

The SOTS-outdoor dataset is used for evaluating various image restoration algorithms, including dehazing, deraining, kernel estimation, motion deblurring, denoising, and low-light enhancement. It focuses on outdoor scenes to assess the performance of these algorithms in real-world conditions, ensuring the removal of atmospheric haze, rain streaks, motion blur, and noise, as well as enhancing visibility in low-light scenarios. The dataset's diverse and realistic images enable comprehensive and robust evaluation of image restoration techniques.

The CSD dataset is primarily used for evaluating and comparing image desnowing methods, focusing on performance metrics and visual quality improvements. It is also utilized to train and test single image desnowing algorithms, particularly those employing hierarchical dual-tree complex wavelet representation and contradict channel loss. This dataset enables researchers to assess the effectiveness of different image restoration techniques in removing snow from images.

The RTTS dataset is used for evaluating image restoration methods, particularly in scenarios where reference images are unavailable. It employs non-reference metrics for quantitative assessment. The dataset addresses various degradations, including noise, rain, and haze, focusing on real-world patterns and their impacts on image quality and visual clarity. This enables researchers to assess the effectiveness of restoration techniques under realistic conditions.

The Practical dataset is primarily used for evaluating image restoration models in various challenging conditions. It is employed for low-light enhancement, deblurring, deraining, and under-display camera restoration. Researchers use it to assess the model's capabilities in enhancing image quality in dark environments, restoring sharpness in motion-blurred images, removing rain streaks, and improving images from under-display cameras. This dataset enables rigorous testing of models across diverse real-world scenarios, ensuring robust performance in practical applications.

The LSDIR dataset is used for training and evaluating image restoration models, particularly focusing on real-world image degradations such as dehazing. It contains a large number of high-resolution images, ranging from 2,000 to 2 million, sourced from various platforms including Flickr. This dataset enables researchers to develop and test restoration models on diverse and realistic image degradations, enhancing the practical applicability of these models.

The TOLED dataset is used for evaluating various image restoration tasks, including raindrop removal, desnowing, low-light enhancement, and under-display image restoration. It assesses the performance and generalization of image restoration methods, particularly in under-display camera images, on both training-seen and training-unseen tasks. This dataset enables researchers to test the effectiveness of restoration techniques in realistic conditions, such as realistic rain, snow, and low-light scenarios.

The Rain13K dataset is used in All-in-One Image Restoration research, specifically for deraining images. It consists of 13,711 training and 4,298 test images, enabling researchers to train models to effectively remove rain streaks and evaluate their performance on synthetic rain images. This dataset facilitates the development and assessment of deraining algorithms, enhancing the clarity and quality of images affected by rain.

The UIEB dataset is used in research to evaluate and compare the visual quality and restoration effectiveness of enhanced underwater images against reference images. It supports the assessment of zero-shot underwater image enhancement techniques, where models trained on a 5-degradation setting are tested without fine-tuning. This dataset facilitates the development and benchmarking of image restoration methods tailored for underwater environments.

The LOLv1 dataset is primarily used for low-light image enhancement research. It consists of 485 training images and 15 test images, enabling researchers to train and validate models like UniUIR. Studies use this dataset to compare the performance of their methods against others, focusing on enhancing backlit and low-light images.

The I-Haze dataset is primarily used for evaluating and validating various image restoration techniques, including dehazing, rain removal, denoising, and super-resolution. It focuses on real-world images with specific conditions such as varying haze, heavy rain streaks, and noise in smartphone camera images. The dataset is also utilized to assess the performance of these techniques on under-display camera images, particularly those from OLED displays, and to enhance resolution and quality in low-resolution image pairs. This enables researchers to test the robustness and effectiveness of their algorithms in diverse and challenging scenarios.

The BSD dataset is primarily used for various image restoration tasks, including deblurring, denoising, dehazing, and deraining. It contains a diverse set of natural images with ground truth annotations, real-world motion-blurred images, and high-resolution urban scenes. Researchers use it to evaluate and train image restoration methods, focusing on enhancing image quality by removing noise, blur, haze, and rain streaks while preserving important features and textures.

The Outdoor-Rain dataset is used to train and evaluate the AllWeather model for various image restoration tasks, including rain image restoration, raindrop removal, and snow image restoration. It provides real-world outdoor images with varying degrees of raindrop occlusions and diverse, realistic degraded images. The dataset supports the integration of physics models and conditional adversarial learning to enhance the effectiveness of heavy rain image restoration methods.

The 'rain-haze-noise-blur-dark' dataset is used to evaluate all-in-one image restoration models, specifically focusing on synthetic and real outdoor scene degradations such as rain, haze, noise, blur, and low-light conditions. It enables researchers to assess the performance of these models under combined degradations, providing a comprehensive test of their robustness and effectiveness in restoring images with multiple types of distortions.

The Snow100K-S dataset is primarily used for testing and evaluating image restoration algorithms, specifically focusing on rain and snow removal. It includes synthetic snow images with varying intensities and complexities, as well as images with raindrops on camera lenses. Researchers use this dataset to assess the effectiveness of restoration methods in enhancing visibility and clarity in real-world and synthetic scenarios. The dataset's high-resolution and complex images enable detailed performance evaluations of these algorithms.

The SPA+ dataset is used in research for evaluating methods in image restoration, specifically focusing on desnowing, dehazing, and deraining. Researchers employ this dataset to test and assess the performance of their algorithms in removing snow, haze, and rain artifacts from images. The dataset's diverse set of degraded images enables comprehensive evaluation of restoration techniques across various environmental conditions.

The EUVP dataset is used to evaluate techniques for reducing underexposure and blur artifacts in underwater images, enhancing visual perception. Researchers employ this dataset to test and validate image restoration methods, focusing on improving clarity and detail in challenging underwater environments. The dataset's relevance lies in its ability to provide realistic scenarios for assessing these specific image enhancement challenges.

The unseen under-display-camera dataset is used to test and evaluate image restoration techniques, specifically focusing on artifact reduction and image quality enhancement for under-display-camera images. It is also utilized to address issues such as color correction and clarity improvement in underwater images. The dataset enables researchers to assess the effectiveness of various restoration methods in these challenging imaging scenarios.

The Rain13k-Test dataset is used across various image restoration tasks, including deraining, motion deblurring, kernel deblurring, JPEG artifact removal, denoising, and low-light enhancement. It serves as a benchmark to evaluate the effectiveness and performance of algorithms in handling diverse image degradation issues. The dataset's versatility allows researchers to test models under realistic conditions, ensuring robustness and generalizability.

The WEB dataset is primarily used for image restoration and denoising model evaluation and training. It includes a diverse set of images, such as urban scenes and natural images, which are used to test and validate restoration techniques. The dataset's large and varied image collection, ranging from 4,744 to 400 images, enhances the real-world applicability and generalization of denoising and restoration models. Researchers use these images to assess performance, train models, and conduct image quality assessments.

The Motion Deblur dataset is primarily used for motion deblurring, providing real-world and synthetic blurred images along with their sharp counterparts to train and evaluate deblurring algorithms. It is also utilized for various image restoration tasks such as dehazing, raindrop removal, defocus deblurring, real denoising, deraining, desnowing, and JPEG artifact removal. The dataset supports these tasks by offering diverse and realistic image pairs, enabling comprehensive performance assessments and method validations.

The Dense-Haze dataset is primarily used for evaluating and benchmarking various image restoration tasks, including dehazing, deraining, desnowing, motion deblurring, defocus deblurring, real denoising, and JPEG artifact removal. It is employed to test the effectiveness of algorithms in removing haze, rain, snow, blur, noise, and compression artifacts from images. The dataset supports research by providing a diverse set of synthetic and real-world images, enabling comprehensive performance assessments under different environmental conditions.

The SOTS-Indoor dataset is used to evaluate the performance of dehazing methods, particularly in indoor environments. It focuses on comparing metrics such as PSNR and FLOPs between different models, including the proposed method and DehazeFormer-L. This dataset enables researchers to assess and benchmark the effectiveness of dehazing techniques specifically for indoor scenes.

The MEF dataset is primarily used for evaluating image restoration models in various challenging conditions. It is employed for low-light enhancement, deblurring, deraining, and under-display camera restoration. Researchers use it to assess the model's capabilities in enhancing image quality in dark environments, restoring sharpness in motion-blurred images, removing rain streaks, and improving images from under-display cameras. The dataset supports the testing and validation of these models by providing real-world scenarios, ensuring robust performance across different restoration tasks.

The Laion-High-Resolution dataset is used to train an all-in-one image restoration model by selecting 12,225 high-resolution and diverse images. This dataset enables researchers to focus on enhancing image quality through restoration techniques, leveraging its rich and varied content to improve model performance and generalization.

RainDS is utilized across various image and video restoration tasks, including contrast enhancement, deblurring, rain removal, low-light enhancement, and haze removal. It provides diverse image and video pairs, such as multi-exposure, sharp-blurred, synthetic-real rain, low-light-normal light, and hazy-clear images, to train and evaluate restoration models. This dataset enables researchers to develop and test algorithms that improve image and video quality under challenging conditions, enhancing visual clarity and detail.

The ImageNet dataset is used to pre-train transformer encoders, enhancing their generalization capabilities in image restoration tasks. By leveraging its large-scale hierarchical image data, researchers aim to improve the performance of models in various image restoration applications. This pre-training approach helps in addressing challenges related to image quality and consistency across diverse datasets.

The GenDS dataset is used to train and evaluate image restoration models, specifically NAFNet, PromptIR, and Swin Transformer-based models, for all-in-one image restoration. It focuses on improving and comparing model performance metrics such as LPIPS and FID, establishing state-of-the-art results by demonstrating the dataset's effectiveness in enhancing model effectiveness and performance.

ImageNet-C is used to benchmark the robustness of image restoration methods and neural networks by introducing common corruptions and perturbations at varying intensities. This dataset enables researchers to evaluate how well these methods perform under degraded conditions, focusing on the stability and reliability of image restoration techniques.

The Mix Degradations dataset is used to evaluate the performance of ConStyle models converted from U-Net models, specifically focusing on their ability to handle various image degradations. This dataset enables researchers to assess how well these models can manage different types of image degradation, providing insights into their robustness and effectiveness in image restoration tasks.

The Outdoor Training Set (OTS) is primarily used for benchmarking and evaluating single-image dehazing methods. It includes synthetic and real-world images, enabling both subjective and objective assessments of dehazing algorithms. The dataset supports training dehazing models on diverse indoor and outdoor scenes, providing ground truth for synthetic images. It facilitates the comparison of dehazing performance using task-driven metrics, ensuring robust evaluation across various scenarios.

RainDS-syn is used to evaluate various image restoration techniques, including raindrop, snow, and haze removal, as well as low-light image enhancement. It features synthetic images with realistic degradations such as rain streaks, raindrops, snowflakes, and haze, enabling researchers to test and compare the performance of their methods using quantitative metrics. The dataset's large size and high-resolution images facilitate robust evaluation across multiple degradation types.

The LOL-v2 dataset is used to evaluate the AllRestorer model's performance in various image restoration tasks, including haze removal, snow removal, and low-light image enhancement. It assesses the model's ability to improve image quality, clarity, and color accuracy in challenging environmental conditions. The dataset supports comprehensive testing in real-world scenarios, enabling researchers to validate the effectiveness of image restoration techniques across diverse applications.

The EUVP dataset is primarily used for evaluating and enhancing image restoration techniques in challenging visual environments, particularly underwater and under-display camera conditions. It focuses on improving visual quality, clarity, and perception by addressing issues such as color correction, contrast improvement, and the removal of specific degradations like snow artifacts. The dataset enables researchers to test and validate methods iteratively on unseen images, ensuring robust performance in complex scenarios.

The Comprehensive Snow GT SD dataset is used to evaluate image restoration methods, particularly focusing on snowy-clean image pairs. Researchers employ this dataset to assess the performance of these methods in real-world conditions, ensuring that the restoration techniques are effective under challenging snowy environments. This dataset enables rigorous testing and validation of image restoration algorithms by providing realistic scenarios.

The U45 dataset is primarily used to evaluate and benchmark image restoration methods in underwater environments, with a focus on natural lighting conditions. It is employed to test and compare the performance of algorithms like NU2Net in reducing color casts, improving visual clarity, and enhancing structural details. The dataset supports research into the robustness and effectiveness of image enhancement techniques in diverse underwater settings, particularly through visual comparisons and non-reference evaluations.

The T90 dataset is used to assess the effectiveness of underwater image restoration techniques on segmentation performance. Researchers apply the Segment Anything Model (SAM) to restored images from various underwater image restoration (UIR) methods, evaluating how these enhancements improve segmentation accuracy. This dataset enables the comparison of different UIR approaches and their impact on downstream computer vision tasks.

The T-OLED-Val dataset is primarily used for validating various image restoration techniques, including low-resolution image restoration and rain removal. It focuses on enhancing OLED display quality and resolution, as well as improving real-world and synthetic rain-degraded images. The dataset supports super-resolution techniques by providing low-to-high resolution image pairs, enabling researchers to evaluate and refine their models effectively.

The Under-Display-Camera (TOLED) dataset is used to evaluate the performance of AutoDIR in enhancing images captured under challenging conditions. Specifically, it assesses the effectiveness of AutoDIR in improving visual perception in underwater images and handling image degradations typical of under-display cameras. The dataset focuses on restoration quality and robustness, enabling researchers to test and refine image enhancement algorithms.

The MiO100 dataset is used to generate low-quality images with multiple degradations, serving as a benchmark for testing image restoration methods. Researchers employ sequential and prompt learning strategies to evaluate and improve these methods, focusing on the dataset's ability to simulate diverse and complex image degradations. This enables the development and validation of robust image restoration techniques.

The DCIE dataset is used for various image restoration tasks, including desnowing, dehazing, and deblurring, as well as low-light enhancement. It supports research by providing large-scale, real-world datasets for removing snow artifacts, improving visibility in hazy conditions, and correcting motion blur in images and videos. For low-light enhancement, the dataset facilitates contrast and color improvement, noise reduction, and detail preservation using deep learning and multi-exposure fusion techniques.

The LIVE1 dataset is primarily used for image quality assessment and degradation analysis. Researchers employ it to demonstrate the loss of degradation information after processing, focusing on how different image restoration techniques impact the preservation of original image characteristics. This dataset enables detailed evaluations of image degradation and restoration methodologies, providing insights into the effectiveness of various processing techniques.

The Snow100K-L dataset is used for evaluating image restoration models, particularly focusing on general image quality and restoration accuracy. It is specifically employed to assess the effectiveness of methods in removing raindrop and snow distortions from images. This dataset enables researchers to test and compare various restoration techniques, ensuring they can effectively handle different types of image degradations.

The URHI dataset is used to evaluate image restoration performance, particularly for the dehazing task. Researchers leverage statistical features related to fog within the dataset to assess and improve dehazing algorithms. This dataset enables the analysis of how well different methods can remove fog from images, focusing on the effectiveness of statistical techniques in enhancing image clarity.

The FADE dataset is used in dehazing studies to provide a non-reference assessment of haze severity, enabling researchers to evaluate the effectiveness of dehazing algorithms. It focuses on quantifying the quality improvements achieved by these algorithms without relying on reference images, thus facilitating objective comparisons and performance assessments in image restoration research.

The CDD11 dataset is used to evaluate and simulate image restoration under compositional degradations, specifically focusing on the performance of the OneRestore framework. It addresses 11 degradation types, including haze, rain, snow, low-light, and their combinations, to assess real-world restoration demands. This dataset enables researchers to test and improve restoration algorithms by providing a diverse set of degradation scenarios.

The AirNet dataset is used for all-in-one natural image restoration, where it serves as a benchmark to compare the performance of different models. Researchers evaluate its effectiveness in various restoration tasks, focusing on the dataset's ability to support comprehensive image restoration methodologies. This enables detailed performance assessments and advancements in image restoration techniques.

The WeatherStream dataset is used for evaluating dehazing, deraining, and desnowing algorithms on real-world images. It contains 4,500 pairs for dehazing, 4,800 pairs for deraining, and 3,960 pairs for desnowing. Researchers employ this dataset to test and compare the performance of various image restoration techniques, focusing on improving image quality under different weather conditions. The large number of paired images facilitates robust algorithm evaluation and validation.

The Lai [18] dataset is used to evaluate image restoration performance on various degradations, including rain, haze, blur, and noise. It serves as a benchmark for assessing the effectiveness of restoration algorithms in these specific conditions. The dataset enables researchers to compare and validate their methods against established standards, ensuring robustness and reliability in image restoration tasks.

The Singapore maritime dataset is used for enhancing visibility in low-visibility maritime scenes by incorporating depth information. Researchers apply image restoration techniques to address challenges such as poor visibility, focusing on improving the clarity and usability of maritime images. This dataset enables the development and evaluation of algorithms designed to enhance image quality in challenging maritime environments.

Set12 is used to evaluate grayscale image denoising methods, focusing on performance metrics and visual quality. The dataset enables researchers to assess the effectiveness of denoising algorithms through quantitative and qualitative analysis, providing a benchmark for comparing different techniques.
